loans.name: Anarkul's Group

texts.en:
Anarkul B. is the leader of this group. She is thirty-three and married. She has two children of thirteen and eleven years old. Both of them go to school. Her husband is school teacher. Anarkul is also a school teacher. However, they also breed cattle. They started cattle breeding from a purchase of cattle with money that was obtained through sale of vegetables from their garden. They increased the number of cattle to seven. They started cattle breeding six years ago with an initial investment of 6000 soms. Anarkul applied for the loan to buy cattle in order to further increase their number. In the near future, they are planning to make capital repairs to their house with the profits from their business.  

Group members:

Sairagul M. is the treasurer of the group. She is thirty-two and married. She has three children: her son is fifteen and her daughters are twelve and six years old. All of them got to school. Her husband is a builder. Sairagul is a school teacher. Together with her husband, she started cattle breeding from a purchase of cattle with the first salary of her husband. Now, they have been almost four years in cattle breeding and they have significantly increased their herd. Now, they make at least 1000 soms each month on cattle breeding. They are applying for a loan in order to make capital repairs to their house before the winter period. In the future, with the profits from cattle breeding, they are planning to expand their herd as much as possible.

Nuriila R. is thirty-eight and married. She has four children. Her eldest child got married and lives independently. Her younger three children go to school and live with her. She is a teacher of Russian language and Literature at the local school. Her husband breeds cattle. They started cattle breeding with the help of a loan in the amount of 5000 soms. From that moment, they have significantly increased their herd. They have already been  in the cattle breeding business for seven years. They are applying for a loan in order to pay for their son’s education. 

Aidai Z. is thirty-nine and a widow. She has three children. Her elderst child got married and lives independently. Her younger children live with her. They go to school. She is a teacher at the local school. She combines her job as a teacher with cattle breeding. She started cattle breeding fifteen years ago with her husband using money from his salary in the amount of 3000 soms. Now, she is applying for a loan in order to buy cattle for fattening. In the future, she is planning to build a house and buy a car for her family. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Phan S., 26, is married and resides with her husband and their young child in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. and her husband are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 3.30 each per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 300 to build a new house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

loans.use: build a new house

loans.name: Mao

texts.en: Mao D., 47, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia.  This area is known for its quality palm products. D. sells shoes to earn an income of USD 10 per day. Her husband is employed at a magazine company, earning an income of USD 2 per day. D. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more shoes to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more shoes to resell

loans.name: San

texts.en: Mr. San S. is a villager who lives in Phnom Penh, where the people are able to run their businesses well. San S. is married and has two kids, who are no longer in school, but are employed in the garment factories. To pursue a daily income, San S. owns a kiosk inside the market where he sells chickens to citizens who come to buy something for their cooking. He and his wife always travel to the rural areas in order to buy chickens, then slaughter them at their house. The couple has been engaged in this job since early 2005. Presently, San S. has a motorcycle that is not able to carry all of his items. He hopes to have a trailer that he will use to pick up more chickens. This is why San S. decided to borrow a loan for the purpose of buying a trailer.

loans.use: To buy a trailer.

loans.name: En

texts.en: En T., 48, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia.  This area is known for its quality palm products. T. is a farmer and earns USD 1 per day. Her husband buys cows to resell, earning USD 4 per day. T. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a pump to help improve farming. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a water pump

loans.name: Toch

texts.en: Toch D., 33, is widowed and resides with two children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia.  This area is known for its quality palm products. D. is a cleaner at the factory and earns an income of USD 1.6 per day. One of her daughter is a worker at the garment factory, earning an income of USD 1.3 per day. D. is requesting a loan of USD 300 to repair her house.  This is her fifth loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: repair her house

loans.name: Kon Tol

texts.en:
Kon Tol B. lives in Kaoh Reah Leu village, Kandal province.  She was born in 1983.  Kon Tol and her husband are farmers who rent a plot of land to grow papaya and mango to sell to support their family.   Her husband is also a horse cart driver. 

Her problem is that her mango field has a lot of insects. To improve production, Kon Tol is asking for a loan to buy pesticides. She is the mother of two children who are too young to work or study.

loans.use: Buy pesticides.

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en: Chhun S., 41, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. and her husband are employed at a local garment factory for an income of USD 3.3 each per day. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen P., 42, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. P. is a farmer and earns an income of USD 2.5 per day. Her husband produces rice wine, earning an income of USD 3 per day. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase more rice to produce rice wine product. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. P. appears in the photograph with her husband while she is helping her husband to produce rice wine.

loans.use: To buy rice to produce rice wine product.

loans.name: Chy

texts.en:
Chy S. is a hard-working man who has spent his life cultivating crops.  He has pieces of farm fields in which to grow various vegetables. 

Three months after planting he harvests his crops and sells them at the market.  Chy is the father of six children, one of whom is employed and the others go to school.  Chy has had great success growing vegetable.  He is able to plant crops at least twice a year. 

Chy will be used this loan to purchase fertilizer, insecticide, a pump and seeds for planting.

loans.use: Purchasing fertilizer, insecticide, a pump and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie B., age 45, and her husband Eliseo, have four children, one in high school, one in college, and two in elementary school. Melanie works hard to cover daily expenses and her children's education, and for the past five years has been selling fashion bags, electronic items,  and frozen food door-to-door to generate income. 

Melanie is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan to help her purchase additional inventory for sale. The loans allow her to buy in bulk when prices are cheapest, and she hopes that the additional inventory will allow her to attract more customers.

Melanie has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for several loan cycles and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.* She hopes that earnings from her business will be sufficient to cover her children's education costs through graduation.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Seiylkan's Group

texts.en:
Seiylkan S. is the leader of the group. She is 47 and married. She has raised three sons and two daughters; her two older sons and first daughter study at university and the other children are at school. Seiylkan is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband works as a taxi driver; when he is free he helps his wife with her work. Seiylkan started to breed cattle two years ago with an initial investment of 15,000 soms. With that money she purchased two bulls and resold them at a higher price (23,000 soms) after fattening them. With money received from the loan, Seiylkan wants to purchase farm animals to increase the number of cattle. In the future she wants to improve her living conditions and give her children a good education.

Gulbaira K., 48, is married. She has a son and a daughter; the son is a private entrepreneur and the daughter is of preschool age (under 7). Gulbaira and her husband are engaged in cattle breeding; they started this activity two years ago with an initial investment of 20,000 soms. They bought a cow and then after a month that cow was resold at the higher price (30,000 soms). With money received from the loan, Gulbaira wants to purchase cattle for breeding and some part of the loan she will spend to purchase hay.

Guljan I., 54, is married. Her husband works as a teacher at school and Guljan is engaged in livestock breeding. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase farm animals in order to increase the number of livestock. In the future she wants to improve her living conditions.

Roza M. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 45 and married. She has two sons and a daughter; the first son studies at university, the second is at school and the daughter is of preschool age (under 7). Roza is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband works as an electrician. In 2009, Roza bought a bull for 8,000 soms and then, after fattening it, resold it for 11,000 soms. And since then she has been breeding cattle. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase farm animals in order to increase the number of cattle. In the future, she wants to expand her business activity and provide her children with a good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase farm animals.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima is a divorced woman with two boys who all attend school. She has been operating her retail shop for the last six years, selling in a shop to her neighbors and passersby. With the KSH 40,000 she wants to purchase maize flour, wheat flour and cooking oil. Her previous occupation was a restaurant operator. Halima faces the major challenge of creditors taking too long to pay back, hence low realization of profits. She hopes to open a bigger shop in future and sell more stock. Her main aim of working with Yehu is to expand her business. She rents a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

loans.use: To purchase maize flour, wheat flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Elzevir

texts.en:
When Elzevir became a member of Kiva's field partner Ahon Sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she found that she not only received capital from them, but also her second family in the presence of co-members. That is why she enjoys being a part of it. Now, her 3rd loan will be used as additional capital for her sari-sari (variety) store. She will buy different groceries and many other items that are needed for her business.

Elzevir says she is working hard, not only to have a better life for herself, but also to help her parents and her niece in their needs. She is just hoping to have a long life so that she can do this. Elzevir is hoping that, with ASHI's and Kiva's support, there is a big possibility that the family can fulfill its dreams.

Elzevir’s business has been very helpful in achieving her family's dreams. Her greatest hope is that her family will be able to have a good life, as it currently lives in poverty. Her long term goals are to invest and build a better house for the family and to have a full-fledged mini-grocery store.

loans.use: To buy groceries and many other items that are needed for her store

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma B. is from the village of San Juan. She is 40 years old and married. Gemma owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Gemma is just starting this business.

In 2009, Gemma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Gemma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.en:
Rodolfo P. is from the village of Sta. Isabel Norte. He is 47 years old, married and has 7 school-aged children. Rodolfo owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rodolfo has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP during harvest season.

In 2010, Rodolfo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodolfo is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rodolfo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

Amelita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Amelita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

Amelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Amelita is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Amelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Alnie

texts.en:
Alnie F. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 47 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Alnie owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Alnie has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from it.

Alnie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alnie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Alnie from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and supplement the family's income. Alnie wishes for CEVI to continue to expand so more farmers could avail of its programs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a 48-year-old gentleman married to Esther. They have eight children, who all go to school. 

Peter was introduced to Kadet by existing members and this will be his second loan. He plans to purchase additional cattle for resale at a profit. Peter has been in the cattle-selling business for the last 20 years and likes the business since he makes good profit from it.

His future plan is to expand his business and move to other towns to sell his cattle, hence making more profit to sustain his family.

loans.use: To buy cattle for resale

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en: Antonio S. is from the village of General Balao, Solana, Cagayan. He is 32 years old. Antonio is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Antonio provides painting services to local community members. Antonio has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Antonio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Antonio is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Antonio from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is married to Mr. Keino and they have been blessed with two children, aged 8 and 2.5 years old. She runs a business of selling fruits and vegetables like mangoes, bananas, oranges, tomatoes and onions. She has been in the business for six years and she says that it is able to meet all her needs.

Caroline is now applying for her second loan, which she plans to use to purchase additional fruits and vegetables to ensure continued supply to her esteemed customers, whom she says are satisfied with her services.

She plans to buy a plot in the future and develop buildings for renting so that she can earn additional income.

loans.use: To purchase additional fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Gigie

texts.en:
Gigie M. is from the village of Balzain West, Tuguegarao City. She is 26 years old. Gigie is married and has 2 very young children. To make a living, Gigie owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from preparing and selling barbecue pork and chicken for sale. Gigie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gigie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gigie is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Gigie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella C. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 32 years old. Estrella is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Estrella owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. 

Estrella joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Estrella has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Estrella is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Estrella from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Lilian Akinyi

texts.en:
Lilian is a twenty-eight year old mother of two children, Mary and Derick, who are aged four and six years respectively. She is married to a gentleman called Mr. W..

She was introduced to Kadet by existing members and with this second loan, Lilian plans to purchase more shoes for sale. She has been in the business for fourteen years and she has been making sustainable profit.

Her future plan is to expand the business into the wholesale field.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of shoes

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma D. J. is from the village of San Juan, Alicia, Isabela. She is 41 years old. Norma is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Norma owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Norma has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 4000 PHP when she sells her raised animal.

In 2010, Norma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Norma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Mathew Ogada

texts.en:
Mathew Ogada is a forty-year-old father of two and married to one wife. He runs a welding shop where he welds metal doors, windows and other items made of metal.

He was introduced to Kadet by existing members and this is his second loan. With this loan he plans to purchase additional welding materials, i.e. welding rods and welding plates for his welding business.

He hopes to grow his business to other areas outside his current area of operation.

loans.use: To purchase welding rods and welding plates

loans.name: Arthur

In 2010, Arthur joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Desideria

texts.en:
Desideria L. lives in  F. Roska, Brgy. Talisay, Sta. Fe, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  shell craft making and pig fattening businesses. Her common-law husband, who is 32 years old, works as a pedicab driver to earn his living.  She has 4 children who are between 1 month and  15 years old. 

Desideria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 9 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Desideria has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000, which she intends to use to purchase raw materials so that she can continue to save up for the future and for tuition fees and additional capital. Desideria L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honourable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: David Kiptarbey

texts.en:
David Kiptarbey M. is general store keeper in Eldoret two. He has been in this business for the past five years. M. is 43 years old, married and with one child aged 3 years. He also supports three family members who solely depend on him as a guardian. He is able to make a profit of Kenya shillings 35,000 per month.

David is currently accessing his 8th loan term with KADET. He plans to use the money given to him to buy bales of maize meal, baking flour, 10 bags of sugar, 12 containers of cooking oil, dozens of containers of body oil and hair oil. He will use the profits to finish the construction of the hotel building next to his shop. 

His future dream is to construct business premises which have a steady income  to support members of his family.

loans.use: To add items of stock like maize flour, baking flour, fertilizers, dry maize, cosmetics, cooking oil, and sugar

loans.name: Ma.nieves

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her farming and pig fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 8,000.

Ma. Nieves is now borrowing PHP 13,000 so that she can fund operations. This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Ma. Nieves aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

By working hard in her ice cream business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000.

Magdalena is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Magdalena aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.name: Enrique

texts.en:
Enrique A. is from the village of Sta Isabel Norte. He is 38 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Enrique owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Enrique has been engaged in his business for over 9 years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Enrique joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Enrique is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Enrique from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas N., 59, is married and lives with two of her children in Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about US $2 each day and are supported by two children working in a garment factory. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Meas N. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US $1000 to purchase fertilizer and a motorbike for her family’s transportation. She is confident that this loan will allow her to increase her daily income and to better support her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and a motorbike.

This time, for her 6th loan, she is borrowing PHP 13,000, which she intends to use to pay for more pigs so that she can continue to save up for her children's future education. Mercedes T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. loans.name: Felisa

texts.en: Felisa M. is from the village of Cabisera 8. She is 41 years old and is married with two adult children. Felisa owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Felisa joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Felisa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 4th from ASKI. loans.name: Keat

texts.en:
Keat R., 50, is a widow and lives with her four children in Takeo province.

Since 1999, Keat R. has been making and selling rice wine and is able to make about US$5 of income eveR. day. She is also supported by two of her children working in the garment factoR.. This family spends about US$40 on food, US$20 on the children’s education, US$30 on transportation and US$10 on other expenses.

Keat R. is asking for a loan of US$750 to purchase a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her childen to use for commuting

loans.name: Irakoze Ii Group

texts.fr:
Jean de Dieu N. est un commerçant âgé de 38 ans qui habite la localité de Gatumba en  Commune  de Mutimbuzi de la Province de Bujumbura Rural. Il fait le commerce de manioc  au Marché de Gatumba il ya de cela 15 ans. Il a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 10e des études secondaires. Son épouse, Rebecca Ngendanzi est aussi commercante de pommes de terre. Il arrive au 2e cycle dans le crédit communautaire avec Turame. 

Il est père  6 enfants : 2 filles et 4 garçons dont 3 d’entre eux étudient. 
  
Il demande le crédit Kiva avec l’objectif d’avoir un grand capital pour  augmenter la quantité de manioc à vendre dans l’espoir de réaliser un grand bénéfice. Il apprécie beaucoup le crédit Turame-Kiva du fait qu’il est facile à obtenir et les conditions de remboursement sont les plus souples comparativement aux autres institutions de microfinance.

 Il est un des membres du groupe  communautaire « I. II ».
texts.en:
Jean de Dieu N., a member of the I. II community group, is a 38-year-old merchant who lives in the Gatumba area of the Mutimbuzi Commune in the province of Bujumbura Rural. He has been selling manioc at the Gatumba Market for 15 years. He attended school up to 10th grade at the secondary level. His wife, Rebecca Ngendanzi, is also a merchant and sells potatoes. He is on his second loan cycle in the community loan program with Turame. He is the father of six children: two girls and four boys, of whom three are students. He is seeking this loan through Kiva with the goal of having more capital to increase the quantity of manioc for sale, with the hope of realizing a larger profit. He is highly appreciative of the Turame-Kiva loan partnership because the loans are easy to obtain and the repayment terms are smooth, compared to other microfinance institutions.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To have a large capital base to increase the amount of manioc for sale, with the hope of realizing a larger profit

loans.name: Citas

texts.en:
Citas G. is a married woman who lives in Zone 1 , Barangay Bacuyangan, Hinoba-an, Negros Occidental.

Citas earns her living by operating a business selling rice and corn. Her husband, Joaquin, who is 60 years old, works as a laborer and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have four children who are between 25 and 32 years old.

Citas joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past eighteen loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15800 (about US$351), uplifting her family's standard of living.

This time, for her 19th loan, Citas is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use as additional capital and to buy a lot of stock so that she can continue to save for her future and for the future of her grandchildren.

Citas is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.


About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To use as additional capital and to buy a lot of stock

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Meas M. included.

In light of these economic difficulties, Meas M. is asking for a loan of US$750 to purchase a sewing machine for her sister. This will allow the family to expand its daily revenue.

In 2009, Lolita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Kirugu Turibamwe, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
B. Justine is a 48-year old pharmacist. She is hard working and determined to transform her business and her status as long as she still lives. 

The single mother of three children has been running a clinic and pharmacy at the Kirugu Trading Centre in Bushenyi District for close to 18 years. From this work, she has been able to educate her children who are still studying in different institutions of learning as she earns 630,000 Ugandan shillings monthly. 

With this loan she is very optimistic about restocking her business with more drugs and looking forward to turning it into a big pharmacy as her customer numbers have increased. This will enable her to earn more revenue and also to be able to meet her family needs.

loans.use: To purchase medicines.

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en: Nuon S., 52, is a widow farmer who lives with four of her children in Takeo province. Besides farming, she also sells fried bananas, making a combined profit of US $3 a day. Four of her children work in a garment factory. Since her children's transportation costs are so high, Nuon S. would like to take out a loan of US $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Imad

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 35 years old, is single, and lives with his parents.

In 2006 he opened a gift and stationery shop in an area filled with schools, which are his biggest customers. He has a good reputation and is known in his local community.

He is requesting a loan of $3,000 from Kiva partner, CHF-ACSI which he wants to invest in redecorating his shop and increasing his stock. He is aiming to grow his business and improve his family's quality of life.

Rucelinda hopes to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ma. Cecilia

texts.en:
Ma. Cecilia M., 44 years old, is a proud mother of 5 children whose ages range from 2 to 12 years old. The family's main source of income is farming, as Ma. Cecilia's husband is a farmer. Because of her husband's meager farming income, Ma. Cecilia decided to join Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. - Rizal East Branch, a Kiva partner microfinance institution in the Philippines, to start her own business in order to help her husband with their financial needs. Her previous loans were spent in the purchase and sale of livestock, particularly chickens, and from her income she was able to support her family's needs. From then on, all she dreamed of was to increase her capital in order to earn more profit.

Ma. Cecilia maintains her good performance in ASHI until she fully pays her loans. Now she is applying again for a new loan to augment the needed capital for her business. If approved, her plan is to buy and sell live chickens. From her earnings, she has been able to construct housing for her poultry and develop the skills for raising chickens. Her aim is to establish a good business so that she can help in providing for all her family's needs, especially for their education. One of her dreams is to renovate their house. This serves as her motivation in working harder and performing her best as a member of ASHI and KIVA.

loans.use: to buy chicken and feed

loans.name: Ty

texts.en: Ty C., 27, is a professional tailor making US$4 a day in the Takeo province. She is married and has two children, who live at home. Her husband earns approximately US$2.50 a day raising pigs. Ty C. would like a loan of US$800 to purchase more fabrics for her tailoring business.

The weather conditions have been difficult in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. loans.name: Pnpov

texts.en: Pnpov C., 29, is married and lives with her husband and two young children in Takeo province. She raises chickens and also works as a hairdresser from home. On average, she is able to make US$5 in profit a day. Her husband is a staff-person from CEDAC organization. His salary is US$5 per day. Pnpov C. is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase hair dressing tools.

loans.use: To purchase hair dressing tools.

loans.name: Turikumwe Group

texts.fr:
N. Francine, elle appartient dans un groupe solidaire appele TURIKUMWE qui est un groupe dont les membres sont  tous commerçants et ils se garantissent mutuellement, et elle est née à Cyangugu.   l’Ouest du pays, Elle est marié, elle a 3enfants, le plus âgée a7ans, le moins âgée a 3.5ans et son niveau d’éducation est primaire. Elle vit avec sa famille à kicukiro kagarama. Un enfant va a l’école. Francine avec son mari travaillent pour faire vivre et améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Elle fait le commerce des produits aliments dans le marché de Nyabugogo. 
FRANCINE et son groupe travaillent pour stabiliser leur capacité financière. En fait, le groupe a contracté un prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter, chacun des membres les articles de leur commerce et les revendre, une partie du profit est  réinvesti pour maintenir et augmenter leurs chiffres d’affaire du groupe et épargner afin de préparer pour un bon futur des membres et des familles.
N.B:N. Francine est à l'extreme droite portant un enfant
texts.en:
Francine N. was born in Cyangugu, belongs to the solidarity group Turikumwe, whose members are all merchants and guarantee each other financially. She was born in the eastern part of the country. She is married and has 3 children, of whom the eldest is 7 years old and the youngest is 3.5 months. She completed primary school and lives with her family in Kicukiro Kagarama. One of her children attends school. Francine and her husband work to support themselves and improve their family's living conditions. She sells food products at the market in Nyabugogo. Francine and her group work to stabilize their financial capacity. In fact, the group has obtained a loan through Amasezerano Community Banking to buy the items that each of them re-sells. A portion of the profits will be reinvested to maintain and increase their sales, and the rest saved in order to prepare themselves and their families for a better future. N.B. In the photo, Francine N. is at the extreme right, carrying a child.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bananas, potatoes, beans, rice, avocadoes, etc. for resale

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora A. is from the village of Cabisera 8. She is 47 years old. Flora is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Flora owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling meat, fish, fruit and vegetables in the local community. Flora has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Flora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flora is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Flora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

texts.en:
Som S., 50 years-old, owns a shop next to her home where she sells food to people who live in and around her community. She typically makes around $3 of profit each day in order to meet her family needs. Som S. has a life partner in her husband who works as a security guard in a private company. The couple are good parents to their three kids.  One of their children is now married and the other two are still unmarried.

In addition to her shop, Som S. also cultivates rice crops during the coming farming season. To help her hard physical labor in the field, Som S. will be using this loan to buy a pair of cows that she will use to plow the farmland.

loans.use: To buy a pair of cows.

Lagrimas has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lagrimas joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.name: Abadahemana Group

texts.fr:
Ada N. est une commerçante âgée de 48 ans qui habite la Commune  de Rugombo à l’Ouest du Burundi. Elle fait le commerce de haricots  au Marché de Rugombo il ya de cela 7 ans. Elle n’a  pas pu fréquenter l’école parce qu’elle était orpheline. Son époux, Samuel Nduwimana est un cultivateur. Elle arrive au 5e cycle dans le crédit communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle a 5 enfants : 2 filles et 3 garçons âgés de 26 ans, 24 ans, 17ans, 15 ans et 7ans. Trois d’entre eux étudient. 
  
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter la quantité de haricots à commercialiser dans l’espoir de réaliser un grand bénéfice. Elle préfère le crédit Turame-Kiva du fait qu’il présente des facilités liées au remboursement progressif avec un taux d’intérêt bas par rapport aux autres institutions financières mais aussi la garantie matérielle est très facile.

 Elle est une des membres du groupe  communautaire « ABADAHEMANA ».
texts.en:
Ada N., a member of the Abadahemana community loan group, is a 48-year-old merchant living in the Rugombo Commune in western Burundi. She has run a business selling beans at the Rugombo Market for 7 years. She was unable to attend school because she was orphaned. Her husband, Samuel Nduwimana, is a farmer. She has reached her fifth group loan cycle with Turame. She has five children: two girls and three boys, aged 26, 24, 17, 15, and 7. Three of them are students. She is seeking a loan through Kiva to increase the amount of beans she can sell, with the hope of realizing a larger profit. She prefers the Turame-Kiva loan system because it provides an easy and progressive repayment schedule with lower interest rates, as compared to other microfinance institutions, and also because the material guarantee is very easy.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the stock of beans for sale, with the hope realizing a larger profit

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
38-year-old Elma dreams of giving the best to her children in their education and future. She and her husband Romeo hope to build a more accommodating and comfortable living for their family. She has three children: 15-year-old Mark Justine, 11-year-old Mike Joshua, and 10-year-old Miaka Joanna, both in graD. school. To achieve this goal she plans to develop her business.

Elma has proposed a loan amounting Php 35,000 as additional capital for her spare parts business. This loan will be a great help for making their dreams come true and little by little her business selling of spare parts will become a full shop soon. For six years as a member of ASHI she has been trusted with loans that have improved their standard of living. Elma is also a good mother and a good adviser. Even at this young age she motivates her children to finish their studies through college because education is the only thing she can give that other people can’t steal.

She hopes that through her loans from ASHI in partnership with KIVA; someday she will be able to save money for their future. Along with the business success she is dreaming about is the hope to see the graduation of her children through college with degrees and to see them find a steady job.

loans.use: Additional capital for her spare parts business

To make a living, Larry owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Larry has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 20,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Larry joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Larry is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Larry from ASKI. loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda C. is a married woman who lives in C. St., Brgy. Talisay, Sta. Fe, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  food vending and pig fattening businesses. Her husband Crusilo C., who is 51 years old, works as a foreman in a construction firm to earn his living.  They have 7 children who are between 11 and 30 years old. 

Luzviminda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Luzviminda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 16th  loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to pay to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for future for business and the education of her children. Luzviminda C. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Kevin also loves to bake and he recently started baking bread that he sells around his neighborhood. He has plans for opening a bakery someday.

Kevin joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Kevin has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Kevin is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs like seeds and fertilizers. He also plans to buy flour, sugar and other baking ingredients. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Kevin from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support his family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

Since 2003 he has been working at a school in Khashtarak village as a teacher. Simultaneously with his basic teaching work, he is engaged in agricultural activities, particularly land cultivation and sheep breeding. He says that sheep breeding is very tiring work, but the same time it is profitable. With the profits from farming he is supporting his family and their needs.

Now he wants to enlarge his farming venture, so he asks for a 600,000 AMD loan to purchase some sheep and sufficient fodder for the whole winter. Khazhak is a 3rd cycle borrower with “Nor Horizon” UCO LLC, without any payment delays.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena A., age 41, and her husband Arsenio, have one child and work hard to cover daily expenses.  For the past five years Elena has owned and run her own sari-sari store (general store) and cured meats store to generate additional income and supplement the money Arsenio earns as a driver.  

Elena is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000 to help her buy extra groceries and meat, in hopes that the additional inventory will help her attract new customers and expand the business.  

Elena has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for several loan cycles and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*  She hopes that someday the business will generate enough earnings to allow her family to renovate their home.  

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase inventory.

texts.en:
Kymbat M. is the leader of the group. He is 59 and married. He has raised four sons and three daughters. Most of the children are married and live separately with their families, except the youngest daughter, who studies at university. Kymbat and his wife are farmers. They have been breeding livestock since 1990 and with money received from the loan Kymbat wants to purchase a sheep to increase the number of livestock.
 
Anara A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 36 and married. She has two newborn babies. Ten years ago, Anara and her husband started to breed livestock. Selling some animals after fattening makes them enough money to cover their expenditures. Her husband also works as a taxi driver. Anara hopes to obtain the loan, because she needs money to purchase a sheep to increase the number of livestock.

Iskender A., 31, is married. He has a daughter and a son, the daughter is at school and the son is not yet. Iskender and his wife are farmers, and they have been breeding livestock for five years. Selling some farm animals after fattening provides them with 5000 soms per month. That money has made it possible for them to save some money and purchase a vehicle. Iskender hopes to obtain the loan because he needs money to purchase one farm animal to increase the number of livestock, and some portion he will use to cover family expenses.

Nurzat S. is 29 and married. She has two sons, both of them are preschool age (under 7). In order to make money, Nurzat and her husband after their marriage, started to breed livestock. Her husband also works as a taxi driver. With money received from the loan Nurzat wants to purchase a sheep to increase the number of livestock.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a sheep.

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en:
Rachel B. is 60 years old, married, and supports her family by operating 3 business ventures:  general store, arucera (rice mill), and buy and sell. She lives in Sitio Buragwak, Brgy. Manghanoy, La Castellana, Negros Occidental.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, arucera (rice mill), and buy and sell businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,500.

Rachel is now borrowing PHP 49,500 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 40,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Rachel aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty A. is currently in the business of selling fruits such as mangoes, oranges, and green vegetables, and is requesting a loan to stock dried fish and tomatoes to sell.  Betty is 20 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

loans.use: To stock dried fish and tomatoes to sell.

loans.name: Jenifa

texts.en: Jenifa G. is currently in the business of selling oil, rice, charcoal, fish, beans, and simsim at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice, charcoal and beans to sell. Jenifa is 20 years old and is divorced. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: To stock more bags of rice, charcoal and beans to sell.

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en:
Kennedy is an outgoing and hardworking man. He is 34 years old and married. He is blessed with one child who goes to school. He earns a living by distributing condoms, shoes, toothpaste, and sweets. He distributes his products to retail shops, wholesalers and chemists. He has done this business for three years.

At the moment, he wants to add stock of condoms, shoes, toothpaste and sweets. He is therefore requesting 40,000 KES from Faulu Kenya. This will be his first loan from Faulu Kenya with the support of his group. Thanks to Imani group in Faulu Kenya. He dreams that someday, he will start up his own company with a capital of 10 Million shillings.

loans.use: To add stock of condoms, shoes, toothpaste and sweets.

loans.name: Hun

texts.en: Hun S., age 35, is married with three children, all of whom attend school and are dependent on her income. Hun S. is a domestic rice trader who buys rice in bulk at a reasonable cost.  After she mills the rice, she sells her finished rice to people for her income. Her husband is skilled in building ox-carts and uses his knowledge to earn a daily profit. Usually the family generates around $6.50 of profit a day to meet the needs of their family. There are a couple of neighbors selling cows at reasonable prices. Hun S. wants to buy a cow or two to raise for the purpose of selling for a profit. Because she doesn’t have cash, Hun S. decided to request a loan to buy it.

loans.use: To buy a cow or two.

loans.name: Kathem

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 47 years old and is married with three children.

He has been running his own business since 2000 which sells sanitary fittings. He is well-known since he has been in the market for so long and has a good reputation.

He is requesting a loan of $2,400 from Kiva partner, CHF-ACSI, which he wants to invest in expanding his business by adding the adjacent shop to his own.

He is planning to grow his business and open many branches in the future.

loans.use: To expand his business by adding the adjacent shop to his own

loans.name: Rima Group

texts.fr:
Aline C. est une commerçante âgée de 30 ans qui habite  à Rugombo dans la Province de Cibitoke située à l’Ouest du Burundi. Elle fait le commerce de produits alimentaires comme le grain de maïs et le haricot au Marché de Cibitoke.C’est un métier qu’elle exerce depuis 6 mois mais faisait le commerce de bière de banane avant de commencer ce métier. Elle a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 4e année des études primaires. Son époux, Ladislas Ndabanogeye est un cultivateur. Elle arrive au 3e cycle dans le crédit Communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle est mère de 2 garçons âgés de 6ans et 2ans. L’aîné fait la maternelle.
  
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter la quantité de produits alimentaires à vendre dans l’espoir d’avoir un grand bénéfice. Elle espère avoir son propre capital dans l’avenir qui lui permettra de faire un grand business et réaliser ses projets comme la construction de sa propre maison, assurer la scolarité de ses enfants et autres.
 
 Elle  est une des membres du groupe  communautaire « RIMA».
texts.en:
Aline C., a member of the Rima community loan group, is a 30-year-old merchant who lives in Rugombo in the Cibitoke province, located in western Burundi. She runs a business selling food products such as maize and beans at the Cibitoke Market. She has run this business for 6 months, but used to sell banana beer before starting her current business. She attended school through the 4th year of her primary education. Her husband, Ladislas Ndabanogeye, is a farmer. She has reached her third group loan cycle with Turame. She is mother of two boys, aged 6 and 2. The older of the two is in kindergarten. She is seeking this loan from Kiva to increase the quantity of food products she can sell, with the hope of generating a larger profit. She hopes to have her own capital base in the future, which will allow her to run a large business and realize her projects, which include building her own house and ensuring her children's education, among others.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase the quantity of food products for sale, with the hope of generating a larger profit

loans.name: Razakan's Group

texts.en:
Razakan J. is the leader of the group. She is 50 and married. She has raised two sons and a daughter. The daughter and the first son are married and live separately with their families, and the second son is at school. Razakan works as a teacher at school and her husband is a pensioner. Twenty years ago, Razakan and her husband started to breed cattle. They sell some cattle after fattening; in this way they make money to cover their family expenses. With money received from the loan Razakan wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future, she wants to increase the number of cattle as much as possible and leave a good inheritance to her children.

Gulnara J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 46 and married. She has three daughters and two sons, and all of them are at school. Gulnara works as a teacher at school and her husband is a taxi driver. They are engaged in cattle breeding and have three cows, two bulls, two calves and four horses. With money received from the loan, Gulnara wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future she wants to start repairing her house.

Uzak S., 42, is married. He has four sons and all of them are at school. Uzak works as a teacher at school. Eleven years ago, Uzak and his wife started to breed farm animals and now they have twenty animals. Every month Uzak sells some of them to make money. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase some farm animals in order to resell them after fattening at the higher price. In the future, she wants to purchase a computer and repair the shed.

Bakyt K., 40, is married. He has two sons and two daughters; the older daughter is the private entrepreneur and the other children are at school. Eight years ago, Bakyt, with the initial investment of 3000 soms, purchased a variety of convenience goods and then resold them at higher prices in his own kiosk. In this way, he makes 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, he wants to purchase goods to increase the turnover of his business. In the future, Bakyt wants to build a barber shop near the house, and work there as a barber. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 26 year old single man. He has been working as a businessman in the transport industry for three years. He uses his matatu (van) for transport. He employs one person, who assists him as a driver. John needed a way to save his money and access financial support, hence he joined Wazalendo group in Faulu Kenya. He has been guaranteed a loan of 58,000 KES with the group. He will use the loan to service his vehicle.

loans.use: To service his vehicle.

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
This is Nena P., 32, resident of Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Angel P., and mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled in elementary while the oldest child is in high school. By the grace of God, Nena has managed to support her older child's schooling up to high school level. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send them all the way through college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Juanita, as she herself has been a college undergraduate, and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Nena operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings where all of the family members are at home to take part of the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition, but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons, when buying cooked rice and viands cost less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php24,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Nena dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To increase her son's business.

loans.name: Mean

texts.en:
Mean S. was born in 1986 and is a resident of the rural area of Kompong Tom Province. She is married and has a young kid who is still not enrolled in school. 

To make a living, Mean S. built a medium store in front of her home where she sells different types of merchandise to people who live nearby. She sells items such as cooking ingredients, cleaning goods, soft drinks, sweets for kids, and gasoline. She has been engaged in this sector for over four years ago, earning about $10 per day. Mean S. receives help from her husband.

Mean S. is committed to make her business more successful and increase her income, so she is applying for this loan to buy additional supplies and ingredients to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy additional supplies and ingredients to sell to her customers

loans.name: Ineza Group

texts.fr:
Bernadette K. est une commerçante âgée de 30 ans qui habite le quartier Bwiza en  Mairie de Bujumbura. Elle fait le commerce de pagnes pour femmes au Marché de  Bujumbura depuis une année. Elle a fréquenté l’école jusqu’en 6e des études primaires. Son époux, Joseph M. est aussi commerçant de pièces de rechange pour véhicules. Elle arrive au 3e cycle dans le crédit communautaire avec Turame. 

Elle est mère  3 enfants qui étudient. 
  
Elle demande le crédit Kiva pour  augmenter la quantité de pagnes  à vendre dans l’espoir d’avoir un grand bénéfice. Elle espère faire  des épargnes pour assurer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants et construire sa propre maison.

 Elle  est une des membres du groupe  communautaire « INEZA ».
texts.en:
Bernadette K. is a 30 year-old shopkeeper who lives in the Bwiza neighborhood of Bujumbura Mairie. She has been selling pagnes (traditional sarong-like clothing) for women at the Bujumbura Market for a year. She attended school up to the sixth grade of elementary school. Her husband, Joseph M. is also a shopkeeper, selling spare parts for vehicles. She is on her third group loan cycle with Turame. She is the mother of 3 children who are in school. She is asking for a Kiva loan so she can have a larger quantity of pagnes to sell in the hopes of making a large profit. She hopes to save some money to cover the school expenses of her children and to build her own house. She is one of the members of the community group “INEZA.”

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the number of pagnes to sell in the hopes of making a large profit

loans.name: Pok's Group

texts.en:
Mr. P. K., age 63, is the village bank president, having been selected by its twenty-one members. The members of this village live I. Preak Thmei village, Kandal province. With their loan, each member of this village bank hopes to increase his or her income to improve the living of their family.    

Mr. P. K. is a farmer who rents some of his land to cultivate vegetables and jasmine. His wife, Mrs. Thoa Kum, is a flower seller I. the market. With both of their occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. This couple has three children: one is a teacher, one is a car mechanic, and the last one is a construction worker.

I. order to support the farming crop, Mr. P. K. will use the loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate vegetables.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate vegetables

loans.name: Rolinda

texts.en:
This is Rolinda E., 49, resident of Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Federico E. and mother of two college aged young adults. By the grace of God, Rolinda has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard be able to continue supporting her children’s education until they finish college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Rolinda, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Rolinda operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piecemeal rates. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Rolinda dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes to have a successful and stable business other than her store. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Augustus Nyambati

texts.en:
Augustus is 50 years old and a married father to six children (aged between 8 and 16), who are all currently in school. He has a kiosk called 'Tumaini Kiosk' in the Langata Shopping Mall in Nairobi, where he sells products such as bread, sugar, cakes, tea leaves, and maize flour. Augustus has been in the business for 20 years, and dreams of opening a wholesale business. He hopes that within five years he'll be able to have a big shop and open another one in Kibera. 

Augustus has previously taken out two loans from Faulu Kenya, and since becoming a client, he says that he has increased his business and it is now quite stable. With his loan, Augustus plans to purchase products for his shop such as sugar, bread, and maize flour to increase stock at his store.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of sugar, bread, and maize flour.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana L. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 41 years old. Diana is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Diana owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Diana has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 50,000 PHP a month for these activities.
