In 2008, Diana joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Diana has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Diana is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Diana from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase firewood and baking tools.

loans.name: Felicidad

texts.en:
This is Felicidad B., 43, resident of Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Gerry B., a high-speed tailor and dealer, and mother of three children ranging from college to elementary. By the grace of God, Felicidad has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her remaining children all the way through college. A dream for most Filipino parents like Felicidad, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Felicidad operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, and sell them piecemeal with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low sales prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php250 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php30,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Felicidad dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Bolortsetseg

texts.en: Bolortsetseg T. is 31 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Darhan-Uul province of central Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her oldest son and daughter currently attend a local secondary school and her youngest will soon start kindergarten. Her husband, Darkhanchu, operates a taxi service in the local area, using the family car as a taxi. Bolortsetseg operates a small cafe in her town. She serves a variety of traditional Mongolia dishes to her many customers. She opened for business in 2008 and has built a stable customer base, growing her operation in a short time. She has developed her skills as a cook and used her income to improve her customer seating area and to purchase new equipment. She hopes to soon hire more workers and increase her food variety to attract new customers.  Bolortsetseg is a gentle and honest person. She and her husband have used their business success to improve the quality of life of their family. She says "I try very hard to raise my children to be well educated, honest people". Bolortsetseg is requesting a 2,300,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more food for her cafe and begin producing new types of meals.

loans.use: To purchase more food.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 30 years old. Gina is married and has a 1-year-old child. To make a living, Gina owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Gina also raises ducks. She has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4500 PHP per month for these activities.

Gina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Gina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Gina is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure. She also plans to buy feed for the ducks. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Gina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and duck feed.

loans.name: Fahima Farhad Group

texts.en: Fahima is a member of the Fahima Farhad group. She lives in the 4th district of Kabul in Afghanistan. She lives in a 5-member household. Fahima is a tailor and can sew all kinds of different clothes. She is requesting the loan to purchase a sewing machine, as well as other essential materials such as, different kinds and colors of thread, small and big scissors and so on. She is glad that through this loan process she can develop her business, which she hopes to progress further in the near future.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and supplies.

loans.name: Khat

texts.en:
Mrs. Khat N. is a 31-year-old farmer who lives in Kompong Tom Province. Khat N. is married to Mr. Ngim, age 30, who works with her in the farming business. This couple is blessed to two young children, both of whom are attending school. 

As the raiN. season approaches, Khat N. doesn’t have supplies to use on her farm, so she  is asking for a loan in order to buy fertilizer and crop seed for growing. (Mrs. Khat N.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and crop seed

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
This is Emma R., 43, resident of Commonwealth, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Jaime, a tractor operator working at the local pier, and mother of two adults, already working and settled down with their own families. By the grace of God, Emma has managed to support her children's schooling up to college level, a dream for most Filipino parents like Emma as she herself was a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Emma operates a business buying various merchandise from wholesalers and selling it piecemeal with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing and other such products. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Emma dreams of being able to have her own house and lot someday. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buy more varieties of products to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Rose Omwaka

texts.en:
Rose is 39 years old and a married mother of four children (aged 21 years, 13 years, 8 years, and 9 months). The middle two are in school. Rose is a barber at the Tukutane Kinyozi (barber shop), which is located at a very busy 'matatu' (bus) stop in Nairobi. Rose has been in the business for 7 years. Previously, she worked as a housekeeper for the small income of 3,000 Kenyan Shillings a month (about $38 dollars).


Rose describes herself as very hardworking and determined, and she hopes to have a well established barber shop and salon. She has previously taken out one or the other loan from Faulu Kenya, and since becoming a client, Rose says she she has been able to buy more razors and has also been able to educate her children in high school. She dreams of buying a plot of land  for her family in the future.

loans.use: Renovating the premises, buying razors, towels, etc.

loans.name: Haydee

texts.en:
Haydee L. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 44 years old. Haydee is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Haydee owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Haydee works hard to give her children bright futures.

Haydee joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Haydee has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Haydee is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Haydee from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Anara's Group

texts.en:
Anara B. is the leader of this group.  She is 47 and a widow. She has two sons and a daughter. The sons went away to work in Russia and the daughter is preschool age (under 7).  In order to make money Anara breeds farm animals. She has been doing it for sixteen years.  Every month she sells some animals in order to make money to cover family expenses. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase cattle for breeding. In the future Anara plans to repair her house and improve their living conditions. 

Zhyldyz A., 44, is married.  She has four daughters; three of them are married and live separately with their families and the youngest daughter is at school. Zhyldyz works as a secretary and her husband is a pensioner. Eleven years ago with the initial investment of 6000 soms her husband purchased sheep and since that moment Zhyldyz and her husband have been breeding livestock.  Every month they sell some sheep to cover family expenses.  Zhyldyz applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase more sheep to increase the number of livestock.  In the future she wants to repair the shed.
 
Gulgaaky J., 35, is a widow. She has two daughters; both of them are at school. Two years ago her parents gave her two sheep as a present. And then Gulgaaky started to breed livestock. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase more sheep in order to increase the number of livestock.  In the future she wants to purchase a house.

Aizat A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 22 and works as an inspector in the Social Department.  With money received from the loan she wants to improve her living conditions and purchase a fridge. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Richard Njoroge

texts.en: Richard is 36 years old and married, with a 4-year-old son who is in school. He runs a real estate agency in Nairobi called Glory and Virtue. His customers are tenants, and he has been in the business for 8 years. He wants to use his loan to buy a computer and printer to help further establish his business. Since becoming a client of Faulu Kenya, Richard says he is more business-focused. He hopes to expand his business to be the major agent in his district.

loans.use: A computer and printer

loans.name: Ihbayar

texts.en:
Ihbayar D. is 38 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Hovd province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His daughter, Badamtsetseg, attends a local secondary school, and his younger daughter and son are in kindergarten. His wife, Odontuya, helps her husband with the family business. 

Ihbayar manages a vegetable trading business. He plants and grows a variety of vegetables which he sells at the local market in his town. Ihbayar started his vegetable trading business in 2000 and has become an experienced grower over the years. This past season, he had the largest harvest he's ever had. Ihbayar is a very expeditious and level headed person. He is optimistic about the future and hopes to soon build a storage facility so he can preserve vegetables for sale during the winter. He is requesting a 1,300,000 Mongolian tugrug (MNT) loan to begin construction on his storage facility.

loans.use: beginning construction of a storage facility.

loans.name: Otgonjargal

texts.en:
Ms Otgonjargal is a 36-year-old widow and lives with her four children who range in age from 5 to 13. They live in a ger (a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent) in Ulaanbaatar, the Mongolian capital city. 

She used to work for a taxi company until the company was shut down. In 2000 she started her taxi business using a car which she bought on a leasing contract from her former employer. 

Two of her kids attends a secondary school and the other two go to kindergarten. She is a very busy person as a single mother. Her working day starts with taking the kids to school, then she runs her taxi business until it's time to pick her kids up from school, and finally her day ends with doing all the chores around the house. 

A taxi driver registered with a taxi company has a quite profitable and safe job because the company's call center finds them customers. So she wants to be registered with one of them. But that requires that her car is fully equipped with radio transmitter. The reason she is requesting this loan is she wants to buy a radio transceiver for her taxi. After that she can be registered by taxi company and increase her income.

loans.use: outfitting taxi with a radio transceiver

loans.name: Yang

texts.en:
Mrs. Yang R. is 46 years old and the mother of five children: two are single and the other three are married and have already started new families. 

In the beginning of 2007, Yang R. built a small store in front of her home. In her shop, she sells a few grocery items to the neighbors who live near her house in the village. In addition, she and her husband always cultivate crops during the farming season. Yang R. is taking out her first loan to buy a plot of neighboring farmland in a good location for her family, where she will plant more crops.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to plant more crops

loans.name: Armen

texts.en:
Armen T. is 28 years old and lives in Kapan. He is married and has a two-year-old son and a new newborn son too. For about six years Armen has managed his own café where he serves his clients and also takes orders for meal preparation without home delivery.

Armen wants to increase the number of his clients, so he increased the area of his café. With his first Kiva loan Armen was able to install the framework of his café’s roof (which you can see on the photo). Now Armen asks for his second Kiva loan (1,000,000 Armenian dram) to slate his cafe's roof and to repair the inside of his café.

loans.use: repair and construction of a cafe

loans.name: Milkah Nduta

texts.en:
Milkah sells oranges, pineapples, watermelons, and tomatoes in Nairobi, near a church. She has been in this business for 19 years and serves both low and high income clients. She wants to use her loan to buy imported apples, oranges, and grapes, which go for higher prices in the market. 

Milkah is 53 years old and has four children between the ages of 23 to 33, and she is also the landlady of rental houses as another source of income. She describes herself as enterprising and hopes to build more rental houses and act as a landlady in the future. She says she has changed since becoming a client of Faulu Kenya because now she keeps records of her business.

loans.use: importing apples, oranges, and grapes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing constructive materials

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn D., from the town of Sto. Niño, is 28 years old, married. and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Jenelyn owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting rice for sale. She works hard to improve her harvest.

Jenelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. This will be Jenelyn's third loan from CEVI, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Chhuon

texts.en:
Chhuon Y. is a rattan cupboard maker. She is 47 and a married mother blessed with three children. One of them is single and the other two are already married. She has another financial earner in her husband, who fishes in and around the river. 

In addition to their current jobs, the couple has grown a rice crop to get extra income. Chhuon Y. will put this  loan towards planting a rice crop during the approaching farming season.

loans.use: To use towards planting a rice crop

loans.name: Jeanith

texts.en:
Jeanith O. is from the town of Sto Niño. She is 34 years old. Jeanith is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jeanith owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Jeanith hopes her business will grow and she works hard at it.

Jeanith joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeanith has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jeanith is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda M. is from the town of Sto Niño. She is 56 years old. Merlinda is married and has 5 children. To make a living, Merlinda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Merlinda has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Merlinda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Merlinda is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Ma. Nita

texts.en:
Ma. Nita J. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 52 years old. Ma. Nita is married and has 7 children. Her younger children still go to school and she hopes to be able to continue their education. To make a living, Ma. Nita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Ma. Nita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years.

Ma. Nita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Nita has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ma. Nita is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Ma. Nita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Amalia

texts.en:
Amalia S. is a busy entrepreneur who aims to become successful someday by developing her farming business. Her husband closely works with her as a farmer. The couple works together for the hopes of their family. Amalia is thankful to ASHI for the loans they have provided since 2003. Amalia was able to maintain her farm by purchasing fertilizers, rice seeds, and other supplies. She is hoping to further improve their crop production in the future through hard work and the continuous assistance of ASHI and Kiva. 

Amalia's lack of business capital encouraged her to look for financial support from KIVA lenders. She will be pleased if her loan request is granted. She l use the loan wisely by purchasing agricultural supplies for the maintenance of her crop production. Her hard work and determination are her foundation for achieving a better life. They currently live in poverty. 

In addition, the income she gets from the business is very helpful for her business and for sustaining the needs of her family, especially providing school tuition fees and allowances for her three children. Two of the children are college students and the youngest is in high school. She hopes that someday,she can expand her farming business. Amalia is glad for the secured chance of taking this loan and for your support and inspiration. 

Amalia's biggest dream is to have rice production someday. Amalia hopes to maintain a long-term sustainable farming business.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for the maintenance of her crop production.

loans.name: Mrs. Norn Chou Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eight people from Tuol Krang village, Kandal province are applying for this village bank loan;  they will use their portions of the loan for different purposes.  

The members  have selected Mrs. Norn C. as the village bank president. Mrs. Norn C. is 50 years old and a widow with a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory. She works as a farming laborer and she is also a pig breeder who can earn large amounts of money to support her family. Her problem is that her piglets are too small to sell, but she does not have enough money to support them. So to improve her pig-breeding business, Mrs. Norn C. is applying for a loan to buy pig food.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en:
Tungalag B. is 50 years old and lives with her husband in Tuv province in central Mongolia. They have no children and live together in a 'ger', which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. 

Tungalag operates a 'ger'-bracing supply production business. She produces ropes, belts, and straps used in 'ger' construction. After producing her products, she transports them to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, to sell at a large outdoor market. Her customers consist mainly of large wholesale buyers. 

Tungalag started her business in 2000 and has gained much experience as a maker of these products over the years. In 2006, she partnered with 4 others and established a business group. This enabled her to expand her production capacity and grow her customer base. The business group has proven quite successful over the last 5 years and has provided Tungalag with enough income to remodel her home. Today, her average monthly income exceeds 200,000 MNT. 

Tungalag is a kind and gentle person. She is a diligent worker and hopes to continue to grow her business to the point where she can have her own workplace. She is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan to purchase horse manes and tails in order to produce ropes and straps.

loans.use: To purchase horse manes and tails

loans.name: Mary Chor

texts.en:
Mary Chor H. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 23 years old. Mary Chor is married and has 2 very young children. To make a living, Mary Chor owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Mary Chor has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

Mary Chor joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Chor has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Mary Chor is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs. This will be the third loan taken out by Mary Chor from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers, seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Valens

texts.en:
Valens is 37 years old and married with four children who are 1, 4, 7 and 9 years old.  Valens owns a shop where he sells a variety of goods and he has been in this business for a long time.  The business hours are from 6 am to 6 pm every day.

Valens needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.  With this loan, he will purchase a variety of goods including foodstuffs.  With this additional business, Valens will hopefully earn more profits, which in turn will allow him to keep reinvesting for better financial stability in his future business and to improve the living style of his family.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of goods including foodstuffs

loans.name: Srey Pov's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreypov L., 25, is the village bank president, having been selected by the group's twenty-three members. The members of this village loan live in Preak Thmei village, Kandal province. Each member of this group will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses. 

Mrs. Sreypov L. is a flower seller in the market, while her husband, Mr. Phearum Heng, is a farmer who owns a plot of land that he uses to cultivate flowers (jasmine). With these both of occupations, they are able to earn a small income to support their family. In order to increase their income to improve the family's standard of living, Mrs. Sreypov L. will use the loan to buy beautician supplies to support her new business. This couple has a child who is age 5 and not in school yet.

loans.use: To buy beautician supplies to support her new business

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip is 34 years old and married to a teacher.  He is blessed with two children; Belvin, 4, and Wesley, 9 months old.  He has been operating Baby Joy Junior Academy for four years.  He has employed eleven teachers.  In addition, he sells sweets for more income.   He is glad to be a member of New Jerusalem group in Faulu Kenya because he can easily access loans. 

He previously took out a loan of 20,000 KES which he used on the business.  He has been allowed to take out another loan of 40,000 KES.  He will use the money to purchase desks and seats for teachers.  In ten years, he wants to have full ownership of the land where he has built his school. This will enable him to build a secondary school and a college.

loans.use: To purchase desks and seats for teachers

loans.name: Gulumkan's Group

texts.en:
Gulumkan T. is the leader of this group. She is 46 and married.  She has a son who is 21 and studies at university. Ten years ago with the initial investment of 10,000 soms Gulumkan and her husband started to breed livestock. They have twenty sheep and four cows. Every month they sell one sheep to cover family expenses.  Gulumkan applied for the loan because she needs money to increase the number of livestock she has.  In the future she wants to purchase a vehicle.

Symbatkan K. is the treasurer of the group. She is 45 and a widow.  She has a son and a daughter. The son studies at university and the daughter is at school. Two years ago,with the initial investment of 4000 soms, Symbatkan started to breed livestock. With that money she purchased two sheep and now she increased their number to seven. With money received from the loan she wants to improve her living conditions and purchase household appliances. 

Asanbek I., 50, is married. He has four daughters and a son.  Asanbek works as a taxi driver and his wife is a nurse.  Five years ago, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, he purchased sheep and started to breed livestock.  Selling some sheep after fattening he makes 5000 soms per month. He hopes to obtain the loan because he needs money to purchase some farm animals to increase the number of livestock. 

Erkinbu T. is 59 and married. She has two daughters and a son.  Her first daughter studies at university, the second is at school, and the son is working. Five years ago with the initial investment of 5000 soms Erkinbu started to sell convenience goods. In this way she makes 5000 soms per month. Her husband works as a mechanic on the power station.  With money received from the loan, Erkinbu wants to increase the turnover of her business activity. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en:
Jerry B. is from the town of Sto. Niño. He is 31 years old. Jerry is married and has one child. He is involved in farming and has been planting and harvesting rice for more than 5 years now. He also grows hogs for fattening and sale. Jerry is working hard to improve his business. He says he wants to have a stable income so he can also sustain the growing needs in his household.

Jerry joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jerry has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Jerry is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and feed for the pigs. This will be the third loan taken out by Jerry from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and feed for the pigs

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Mrs. P. has been in the farming business for years. She plants various crops to earn a living and typically generates a formal income. 

Her husband earns a living as an animal trader. He always goes to buy oxen in the rural areas from farmers and re-sells those oxen to gain income. This couple has been married for years and has two children. Both of the children are going to school. P. sees that her husband’s business is profitable and she hopes to sustain it by accumulating a larger quantity of oxen using a Kiva loan.

loans.use: To buy oxen to sell

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a 48-year old man with four children. He hopes to educate his children to university level. 

For two years, Peter has been operating a matatu (van) business. He also runs a tailoring shop for extra income. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has learned customer care skills through trainings. In addition, he has absorbed the culture of saving his money on weekly basis.

Peter has previously taken out a loan from Faulu Kenya, which he used to boost the business. He is now requesting another loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy two new tyres, a car battery, and to have his vehicle serviced. He believes that with a well-serviced matatu (van) he will work more efficiently. 

Peter says that he is a man of integrity with a great passion to succeed in life. He is determined to own a fleet of matatus in five years.

loans.use: To buy new tyres, a car battery, and have his vehicle serviced.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion S. is from the town of Santo Niño. She is 59 years old. To make a living, Salvacion owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Salvacion has been engaged in her business for over 25 years.

Salvacion joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Salvacion has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Salvacion is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional rice seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Salvacion from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional rice seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Lynda

texts.en:
Lynda is 32 years old.  She is married and has one child who is in school.  She is a tailor who mainly makes children's outfits to earn a living.  She started the business two years ago and has two employees.  She was previously selling second-hand clothes.

She joined Favour Self Help group in Faulu Kenya.  The members guarantee each others loans. Through the group, she has been able to set up a business premise and bought a sewing machine.  She has requested a loan of 30,000 KES to buy fabric and thread.  She hopes to educate her daughter so that she may have a bright future.

loans.use: To buy fabric and thread

loans.name: Carlito

texts.en:
Carlito G. is from the town of Santo Niño. He is 54 years old and married. To make a living, Carlito owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Carlito has been engaged in his business for over 30 years. He works his best to improve his harvest.

Carlito joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carlito has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Carlito is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Carlito from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to their house.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en:
Chhum K., age 51, owns and operates a handicraft business whose main activity is selling rattan cupboards. She sells rattan that she weaves herself or that she orders from other weavers who live in the village. 

She was married, but her husband died of senility years ago. She currently lives with a son who is skilled in repairing mobile phones; another one of her children has gotten married and lives separately. Chhum K. has requested a loan for son to use to increase his business capital.

loans.use: To increase the business capital

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en:
Ma. Fe P. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 48 years old has 8 children. Fe has been involved in farming for over 10 years. She plants and harvests rice crops. She also grows pigs to fatten and sell. Fe's older children help her in farming. She hopes to have a stable source of income.

Ma. Fe joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Fe is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She will also use the loan to buy feeds and piglet. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs. She will also use the loan to buy feeds and piglet

loans.name: Karine

texts.en:
Karine A. is from the village of Artik in the Shirak region of Armenia. She is married with a daughter and two sons. She has a high-school education from her hometown of Artik.  

Karine has been working as a self-employed businesswomen selling clothes. She is looking for a loan to stock her inventory of clothes for the autumn season. She considers herself an honest, hard worker.  

With a loan, she is expecting to increase the family income by 30%.  In addition to providing for her family, Karine also supports the family of her husband’s brother and her cousin. It is her dream to purchase a retail office for her business; currently she is renting office space. By increasing her inventory, she will be able to increase the variety of clothes available for customers.  

She has lived in Artik her whole life and enjoys being close to relatives and friends.

loans.use: Stock inventory of clothes

loans.name: Mrs. Thav Chea Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is for ten people who live in Ta Nu village, Kandal province. They each will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Thav C. is the village bank president, selected by the other members. She is a 38-year-old widow with a child who is ten years old. 

She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family; she also works as a farm laborer. Her problE. is that her field is ready to be plowed but she does not have the money to support the business. So, to enable production of the rice crop, Mrs. Thav C. is seeking a loan to rent a plowing machine to plow her field.

loans.use: To rent a plowing machine to plow her field

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen M., 69 years old, owns a small shop next to her house where she sells food to people who come across the road. She typically makes around $3 of profit each day to meet what her family needs. She was married, but her husband died of senility years ago. Although she is now a single woman, she is a fantastic mother who has tried to ensure that her children have suitable jobs. 

Pen M. is running her business well because she has skills in communication that she uses with her customers. However, her income is not very much as her business has come to a low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. Pen M. wishes to have more money to increase her capital, which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan.

loans.use: To increase her capital, which will allow her to improve her profits

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en: Ruth D. is from the town of Banga. She is 58 years old. Ruth is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Ruth raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Ruth is also involved in making barquillios, a thin-rolled cookie that is popular in the Philippines. She sells barquillios to friends and other people in her community. Ruth joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruth has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ruth is requesting a new loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase livestock feed and ingredients for making barquillios. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Ruth from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & ingredients for making "barquillios"

loans.name: Aghavni

texts.en: Aghavni A. lives in the Shirak region of Armenia in the village of Arapy.  She is especially proud of her three children – 2 daughters (15 and 19 years old) and her 17 year old son.  Over the past ten years Aghavni has been engaged in raising livestock and growing vegetables and wheat.  She chose this business because agricultural production is the main economic opportunity in Arapy.  She wants a loan to purchase fuel for the wheat harvest and for cattle feed.  Aghavni expects this expansion of her business to increase the family income by 25%.  With these funds she will be able to pay the tuition fees for her children’s education.  Aghavni really enjoys living in Arapy and is fortunate to have many friends and family as neighbors.  With success she intends to continue growing her business.

loans.use: fuel and feed

loans.name: Sophoun's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. SophoU. S., 31, is married with three children who are attending the local public school. She owns a small coffee shop while her husband, Mr. Vicheth Chuon, is a fisherman. Between these two occupations they are able to earn a small income to support their family.

SophoU. was selected as Lvea Sa Kandal’s village bank president in Kandal province by seventeen members of this village loan. All its members will use their portions of the loan for different purposes. In order to support her husband’s fishing, SophoU. decided to ask for a loan to buy a fishing boat and fishing supplies.

loans.use: To buy a boat and fishing supplies

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian Z. is from the town of Banga. She is 42 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. She is a farmer and has been planting and harvesting rice for more than a few years now. She also sells pork meat to the market. Sometimes, she makes "chorizo", a pork sausage famous in the Philippines. Lilian wants to have a successful business.

Lilian joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lilian is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be her 4th loan from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Nanar

texts.en:
Nanar G. resides in the village of Vahramaberd in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is a proud resident of Vahramaberd and has a reputation as a disciplined hard worker.  Nanar has diversified her wheat growing business by also renting a small shop for retail trade.  She had a particular need to fund the tuition costs of college for her son and daughter.  Nanar also has a second daughter in the sixth grade.  

With a loan Nanar will increase the inventory of her small retail store and also use some of the funds to harvest the wheat crop.  She is planning to increase the family income by 15% with the loan.  The expected profit has been earmarked for the children’s education.  She considers herself lucky to be surrounded by her extended family in Vahramaberd.

loans.use: to increase store inventory

loans.name: Anisa

texts.en:
Anisa K. is a resident of Karabalta, a small city near Bishkek. She is 59 and married with a son and a daughter, both of them married. Twenty years ago with the initial investment of 1000 soms Anisa started to sell cosmetics in the market. In this way she makes 35000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to save money and purchase a house and then a container. Anisa applies for the loan because she needs money to purchase more cosmetics to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she wants to save money and provide a good education to her grandchildren.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics

loans.name: Hanily

texts.en:
Hanily E. is from the town of Banga. She is 48 years old and married and with four children. To make a living, Hanily owns a retail store selling clothing and shoes. Hanily also helps her husband in their rice farm to make it productive.

Hanily joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI and is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell and farm supplies. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Hanily from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell and farm supplies

loans.name: Calvince

texts.en: Calvince is a 24-year-old married man with one child. He runs Kenwood's workshop where he makes and sells furniture. He has been in the business for six years and has two employees. He also sells building materials to earn extra income to provide for his family. He is an active member of Mutarakwa group in Faulu Kenya and attends the group meetings regularly. He has previously repaid one loan from Faulu Kenya. He has requested 30,000 KES to add stone and timber to his business supplies. He also hopes to start a tailoring business in the future.

loans.use: To add stones and timber to his building supplies

loans.name: Youghaber

texts.en: Youghaber H. is a life-long resident of Artik village.  Artik is located in the Shirak region of Armenia.  Youghaber has five beautiful children: three daughters (10, 15 and 16 years old) and two sons (18 and 20 years old).  Due to medical conditions, Youghaber’s husband is unable to work on their small farm.  Youghaber has been engaged in raising cattle for the past four years.  In order to grow her business, she is looking for a loan.  She will use the funds to increase her livestock and purchase feed.  She considers herself a hardworking, honest farmer.  She expects the family income to grow by 20% with the additional business investment.  Youghaber will use the funds to support her children’s education, pay medical expenses for her husband and also save a bit of the funds.  Her dream is to build a house for her family.  Youghaber enjoys living in Artik.  She is fortunate to have many relatives and friends living nearby.

loans.use: To purchase calves and feed

loans.name: 040701-Thanh Xuan- Hoang Truong Group

texts.en:
Thao L. T. (77) is a 32-year-old femaL. living in the town of Hoang Hoa.  Thao is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 040701-Thanh xuan- Hoang T.. 

Thao is married and has three school-aged children.  To making a living, Thao operates a family member's business raising cattL. for saL..  Thao has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2009, Thao joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Thao has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  The loan will be the second loan taken out by Thao from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Thao plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Hoang T. T.  (18) is a 48-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


2.  Tron V. T.  (76) is a 49-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


3.  Thanh L. T.  (79) is a 36-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


4.  Hong L. T.  (80) is a 47-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


5.  Tho L. T.  (78) is a 37-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Thao L. T. (77) là 32 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang Hoa.  Thao là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 040701-Thanh xuan- Hoang T. (040701-Thanh xuan- Hoang T.).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Thao thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Thao kiếm được khoảng 2,000,000 VND.  Vào 2009, Thao đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Thao đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Hoang T. T.  (18) là 48 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


2.  Tron V. T.  (76) là 49 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


3.  Thanh L. T.  (79) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


4.  Hong L. T.  (80) là 47 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


5.  Tho L. T.  (78) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena E. is from the town of Banga. She is 51 years old, married and has 3 children. To make a living, Elena owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. Elena also runs a sari-sari (convenience) store where she sells a variety of different products.

Elena joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI.

Elena is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs (fertilizers, etc.) and additional store inventory. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Elena from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs (fertilizers, etc.) and additional store inventory

loans.name: Knarik

texts.en:
Knarik M. lives in the village of Arapi in the Shirak region of Armenia.  Even though Knarik has a college education, economic opportunities were very limited and she chose agriculture for self employment.  For the past 22 years, Knarik has been engaged in livestock production and wheat production.

She is married with two sons aged 20 and 22 years old.  As she values education, she is particularly keen to have her children continue their studies.  She is seeking a loan to purchase fuel and to rent equipment to organize the wheat harvest.  With the loan she expects the family income to increase by 20%.  These funds will be dedicated to her children’s college tuition and repairing their house.  Knarik enjoys working on the land and especially enjoys living so close to nature.

loans.use: fuel and rental equipment

loans.name: C2133 Duterimbere Group

texts.en:
Caline was born in 1975 and is married with 3 children; the first one is 12, the next is 10, and the last is 7 years old. Caline is  a businesswoman but her husband is jobless and because of that, Caline works hard in order to provide for her family. Caline's business is well-known which is an advantage for her; the hours of her daily activities are from 8 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day except on Sunday. She has her own business, but she is also group leader of three people with various businesses.

Caline is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing more bales of clothes. Once this loan is given, Caline will be able to attract more customers and satisfy their needs. With this customer satisfaction, she will be able to earn more profit to use in her business and for her family.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en: Mercedes C. is from the town of Banga. She is 59 years old, married and has 4 children. To make a living, Mercedes owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Mercedes has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month from these activities. Mercedes joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercedes has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Mercedes is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Mercedes from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly in recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but, additionally, savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ruzanna

texts.en:
Ruzanna M.
Ruzanna resides in the village of Voghji in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is married with a 22-year-old daughter and a 26-year-old son.  She has a high school education with technical training as a mechanic.  She has been working in cattle breeding and growing vegetables for the past 20 years.  She is planning to expand her cattle breeding business by purchasing additional cattle with a loan.  She already has customers willing to purchase her new cattle.  With the loan she expects to increase the family income by 20% and will use some of the proceeds for repairing the family home.  She is a hard working woman with a good reputation in Voghji.  Ruzanna has many family and friends living near the family farm.  Even though many villagers are engaged in similar businesses, Ruzanna’s excellent relations with her clients enable her to always sell her products.

loans.use: additional calves

loans.name: Samvel

texts.en:
Samvel M.
Samvel M. is a long term resident of the Kaps village located in the Shirak region of Armenia.  He has been engaged in cattle breeding and growing vegetables for over twenty years.  He is happily married with three children; a 7-year-old daughter, a 14-year-old daughter, and an 8-year-old son.  He supports his brother in Gyumri with vegetables and meat from his farm.  He would like a loan to purchase additional cattle and fertilizers.  By growing his business he is expecting the family income to increase by 20%.  The additional funds will be used for home and farm renovations and supporting the education of his children.  Samvel particularly enjoys living on a farm and the beautiful environment of the Kaps area.  Most people of Kaps are engaged in agricultural production and Samvel has many close relatives nearby.

loans.use: cattle and fertilizers

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a 50-year-old married man with five children; 28-year-old Naomi, 26-year-old Priscilla, 24-year-old Gabriel, 22-year-old Nathaniel, and 13-year-old Hellen. Hellen is still in school but the rest have finished school. Peter has been operating a retail shop for fifteen years to earn a living. He has been able to expand the business through Elshaddai group in Faulu Kenya. This is because he uses his savings with the group to invest in his business. He has applied for his first loan which he will use to purchase sugar, wheat flour, maize flour and soda. He hopes to expand his shop into wholesale in the future. He describes himself as a hardworking and honest man.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, wheat flour, maize flour and soda.

loans.name: Chynara

texts.en:
Chynara D. is a resident of Kant, a small pleasant city near Bishkek. Chynara is 46 years old and she is married. She has two sons and a daughter. The daughter studies at school and the sons sell household appliances in a pavilion. Four years ago, Chynara started to sew blankets and sell them to make money. She started with the initial investment of 3000 soms. She also sells curtains, and in this way she makes 15,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to start repairing her house and purchase a vehicle. 

Chynara applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase fabrics and materials for sewing curtains.  In the future she wants to purchase a flat for her sons and provide her daughter with good education.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Lusine

texts.en:
Lusine S. is a seasoned farmer from the village of Ghazanchi in the Shirak region of Armenia.  She is married with a 16-year-old daughter and an 18-year-old son.  She is particularly proud of her children’s desire to study at the university in the city of Gyumri (Armenia). 

 With this in mind, Lusine has planned to expand her cattle breeding business with a loan.  She is expecting to purchase additional calves.  This business investment can increase the family income by around 30%.  Much of the additional funds will be saved to support her children’s university education.  Lusine’s dream is to be able to purchase a family home in Gyumri for her children during their university studies.  With twenty years of cattle breeding experience, she is confident that her business plan will be successful.

loans.use: purchase calves

loans.name: Davlatbegim

texts.en:
C. Davlatbegim is divorced and has 4 children. She runs a business selling women’s shoes and fabrics for sewing national dresses at the central market of Kumsangir, Tajikistan. Her business exhibits good economic characteristics and fundamentals. Davlatbegim has a unique talent for identifying new opportunities and determining appropriate growth policies for her business. She has been in this trade for 6 years.

 Davlatbegim would like to get a loan of 3,000 USD to increase her working capital so that she can continue working to improve her business. We believe her natural ability to please her customers by perceiving their needs and offering speedy, courteous service will help Davlatbegim achieve her goals, sustain her success, and succeed as an entrepreneur.  
 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Increasing working capital with the purpose of development of business

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en: Susanna S. is from the village of Bavra located in the Shirak region of Armenia.  Susanna is married with three children – two daughters (27 and 25 years old) and one son (20 years old).  She has a high school education with 7 years of experience farming and running small businesses.  She particularly sees growth potential in her small retail shop.  She is looking for a loan to increase her shop's merchandise.  With this investment she expects the family income to increase by 15%.  These proceeds will be used to support her daughters' families, save money for her son’s upcoming wedding, and reinvest in the business.  She enjoys living in Bavra with its agricultural lifestyle and beautiful environment.

loans.use: additional merchandise

loans.name: Rahimakhon

texts.en:
Rahimakhon H. is a 54-year-old widowed mother who has sold clothes for children and teenagers at her local market for the past 16 years. Her enterprise will enable her to pay for her children to complete their education. Rahimakhon is requesting this loan to buy more bales of clothes to increase the variety of her stock.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: 040702-Thanh Xuan- Hoang Truong Group

texts.en:
Mai L. T. (45) is a 34-year-old femaL. living in the town of Hoang Hoa.  Mai is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 040702-Thanh xuan- Hoang Truong' 

Mai is married and has three school-aged children.  To make a living, Mai operates a family member's business harvesting & selling wild-caught fish in the local community.  Mai has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,600,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2004, Mai joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Mai has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets.  She is now requesting a new loan of 4,248,000 VND, which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets.  The loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Mai from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Mai plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
